For each pair of words, determine whether their Hebrew translations rhyme. If they do, output the pair of rhyming words in Hebrew. If not, output NONE.
lesson, light

data.sampled:
To determine if the Hebrew translations rhyme, we need to consider both the vowel sounds and the consonant sounds. Here's how we can do it:
- In Hebrew, when consonants are at the beginning or end of a word, they make a sound called a "trope". If two words have the same consonant sounds at the beginning or end, they are considered to have the same "trope" and will therefore rhyme.
- In Hebrew, vowels are indicated by dots (vowels are not pronounced in Hebrew). When two words have the same vowel sounds, they are considered to have the same "vowel sound" (שבילי) and will also rhyme.
- If a word has more than one vowel sound, we can group them into a single sound for comparison purposes (e.g. "ey typh" = "eyes").
- So to check if two words rhyme, we can compare their "trope" and "vowel sound".
- "lesson" has no "trope" (the only consonant is "s") and no "vowel sound" (there are no vowels in the word). So we can't compare these with other words.
- "light" has the "trope" "l" and the "vowel sound" "e". We can compare these with other words that have the "trope" "l" and the "vowel sound" "e" (e.g. "lelo" = "light" and "lomd" = "world").
- So the two words "lesson" and "light" do not rhyme in Hebrew because they have different "trope" and "vowel sound". We can output "NONE" for this pair of words.
